sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction H2(g) + CO2(g) -> H2O(g) + CO(g), given the following standard enthalpies of formation: delta Hf(H2O) = -286 kJ/mol, delta Hf (CO) = -110.5 kJ/mol, delta Hf (CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol, and delta Hf (H2) = 0 kJ/mol?
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔHf(products) - Σ ΔHf(reactants)

For the given reaction, H2(g) + CO2(g) -> H2O(g) + CO(g), we have:

ΔH_reaction = [ΔHf(H2O) + ΔHf(CO)] - [ΔHf(H2) + ΔHf(CO2)]

Plugging in the given values:

ΔH_reaction = [(-286 kJ/mol) + (-110.5 kJ/mol)] - [(0 kJ/mol) + (-393.5 kJ/mol)]

ΔH_reaction = (-396.5 kJ/mol) - (-393.5 kJ/mol)

ΔH_reaction = -3 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -3 kJ/mol.
